facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2161 of 1969 is an appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated April 5, 1968 of the Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated April 5, 1968 of the Kerala High Court at Ernakulam in Incometax Referred Case No. 16 of 1962.

facts.text: This Court allowed Appeal No. 324 of 1965 on September 20, 1966 and remanded the case for re-hearing.

anchor.surface_text: This is a second round of litigation because on the first occasion this Court allowed Appeal No. 324 of 1965 on September 20, 1966 and remanded the case for being re-heard

facts.text: Division Bench of Kerala High Court (Raghavan J. and Issac J.) heard the matter post-remand but differed in opinion, placed before Mathew J. who agreed with Raghavan J.

anchor.surface_text: and dealt with in accordance with the directions given in that judgment. After the matter went back a Division Bench of the Kerala High Court, Raghavan, J.  as he then was  and Issac, J. heard the matter but as there was difference of opinion

facts.text: Appellant is a limited company incorporated under the Travancore Companies Regulation carrying on business in Kerala of manufacturing sugar, running a distillery and tincture factory.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a limited companypany incorporated under the Travancore Companies Regulation and is carrying on business, in the State of Kerala of manufacturing sugar, running a distillery and also a tincture factory.

facts.text: Appellant-company was floated to take over business assets of Travancore Sugars Ltd. (being wound up, State Government held largest shares), Government Distillery at Nagercoil and Government Tincture Factory at Trivandrum.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant- companypany was floated with a view to taking over the business assets of a companypany called Travancore Sugars Ltd.  which was being would up and in which the State Government held the largest number of shares , the Government Distillery at Nagercoil

facts.text: Agreement dated June 18, 1937 entered between Government of Travancore and Sir William Wright on behalf of Parry Co. Ltd., promoters of appellant-company.

anchor.surface_text: and the business assets of the Government Tincture Factory at Trivandrum. For this purpose an agreement dated June 18, 1937, was entered into between the Government of Travancore and Sir William Wright on behalf of Parry Co. Ltd., the promoters of the appellant-company.

facts.text: Under agreement dated June 18, 1937, Clause 3 provided cash consideration for sale of assets of Travancore Sugars Ltd. as 3.25 lakh rupees.

anchor.surface_text: Under the said agreement the assets of all the three companycerns were agreed to be sold by the Government of Travancore to the appellant-company. Clause 3 of the agreement provided that the cash companysideration for the sale of assets of the Travancore Sugars Ltd. shall be 3.25lakh rupees.

facts.text: Clause 4(a) of June 18, 1937 agreement: cash consideration for Government Distillery arrived at by joint valuation by engineers appointed by parties.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 4 a  provided that the cash companysiderationfor the sale of the Government Distillery shall be arrived at asa result of joint valuation by the engineers to be appointed bythe parties.

facts.text: Clause 5(a) of June 18, 1937 agreement: cash consideration for Government Tincture Factory assets as value according to books.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 a  stated that the cash companysideration for the sale of assets of the Government Tincture Factory shall be the value according to the books.

facts.text: Under clauses 4(b) and 4(c) of June 18, 1937 agreement, Government undertook to recognize transfer of distillery licence and secure continuance for 5 years after existing licence.

anchor.surface_text: Under clause 4 b  and  c  of the agreement the Government undertook to recognise the transfer of the licence from the licensees of the distillery to the appellant and to secure to it the companytinuance of the licence for a companytinuous period of five years after the termination of the then existing licence.

facts.text: Clause 5(b) of June 18, 1937 agreement: Government agreed to purchase pharmaceutical products from appellant's tincture factory for medical requirements.

anchor.surface_text: Under clause 5 b  of the agreement the Government agreed to purchase the pharmaceutical products manufactured by the appellant in the tincture factory, for its medical requirements.

facts.text: Clause 7 of June 18, 1937 agreement: Government entitled to 20% of net profits per year, max Rs.40,000, after deductions including depreciation and secretaries' remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: The Government shall be entitled to twenty per cent of the net profits earned by the companypany in every year subject however to a maximum of rupees forty thousand per annum, such net profits for the purposes of this clause to be ascertained by deduction of expenditure from gross income and also after-- provision has been made for depreciation at number less than the rates of allowances provided for in the income-tax law for the time being in force, and payment of the secretaries and treasurers remuneration.

facts.text: Agreement dated January 28, 1947 substituted clause 7: Government entitled to 10% of net profits as assessed to income-tax in Travancore.

anchor.surface_text: By another agreement dated January 28, 1947, the following clause was substituted for the above caluse 7 of the original agreement The Government shall be entitled to ten per centum of the net profits of the companypany in every year. For the purpose of this clause net profits means the amount for which the companypanys audited profits in any year are assessed to income-tax in the State of Travancore.

facts.text: For assessment year 1958-59 (previous year May 1, 1956 to April 30, 1957), amount payable to Government under clause 7 was Rs. 42,480.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1958-59  the companyresponding previous year being May 1, 1956, to April 30, 1957  the amount payable to the Government under the aforesaid clause 7 came to Rs. 42,480.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed deduction of Rs.42,480 as mere sharing of profits.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed the claim of the appellant for deduction of this amount on the ground that it was virtually mere sharing of profits after they came into existence.

facts.text: Income Tax Appellate Tribunal allowed the deduction relying on British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd. v. Harris.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred an appeal against the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner to the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal which held that the case came within the principle of the decision in British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd. v. Harris  Inspector of Taxes   1939  7 T.R. 101  C.A.  , and that the payment of companymission was an expenditure made in order to earn profits

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to Kerala High Court: Whether payment of Rs.42,480 allowable under section 10 of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: , and that the payment of companymission was an expenditure made in order to earn profits, of the business and number an expenditure paid out of earned profits. In the result the Tribunal allowed the appeal by the companypany. At the instance of the respondent the Tribunal referred the following question of law to the High Court of Kerala.

facts.text: Kerala High Court by judgment dated August 20, 1963 held payment constituted capital expenditure, not allowable under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated August 20, 1963, the High Court held that the payment of the aforesaid amount companystituted capital expenditure and was number allowable under section 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court in previous appeal held payment is revenue expenditure, not capital, overruled High Court, but remanded for other issues.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these facts we are of opinion that the payment of the sum of Rs. 42,480 in the present case is number in the nature of capital expenditure but is in the nature of revenue expenditure and the judgment of the, High Court of Kerala on this point must be over- ruled.

facts.text: On remand, second contention of joint venture not pressed before Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Before that High Court the second companytention whether the transaction should be treated as a joint venture with an agreement to share profits was number pressed and therefore that matter was number companysidered.

facts.text: Mathew J. held payment is revenue expenditure as per Supreme Court, considered diversion by overriding title and s.10(2)(xv) allowability.

anchor.surface_text: Mathew, J.  as he then was  numbered that the Supreme Court had held that the payment was number in the nature of capital payment but was in the nature of revenue payment because the unpaid purchase price was neither a fixed sum number an amount which companyld be ascertained by any method.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirmed payment of Rs.42,480 is revenue expenditure allowable under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: Once the crucial question is decided by this Court that the expenditure is number of a capital nature but is a revenue expenditure, we should have thought that the matter ended there and that the answer to the reference was certainly in the affirmative.

facts.text: Company had to agree to obligations including 20% (later 10%) profits payment as condition for taking over assets.

facts.text: Under contract, company to engage Travancore labour and staff, take apprentices recommended by Government.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that under the companytract the companypany had to engage only the Travancore labour and staff, that it had to take apprentices recommended by the Government and train them

At the instance of the respondent the Tribunal referred the following question of law to the High Court of Kerala. Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the payment of Rs. 42,480 by the assessee to the Travancore Government under the agreements dated June 18, 1937, and January 28, 1947, was allowable under section 10 of the Income-tax Act?.

anchor.surface_text: Pondicherry Railway Co. Ltd., v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1931 5 I.T.C. 363 58 I.A. 239 in disallowing this item of expenditure The appellant preferred an appeal against the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner to the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal which held that the case came within the principle of the decision in British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd. v. Harris  Inspector of Taxes   1939  7 T.R. 101  C.A.  , and that the payment of commission was an expenditure made in order to earn profits, of the business and not an expenditure paid out of earned profits.

anchor.surface_text: Pondicherry Rly. Co. Income-tax Commissioner 1  was sought to be distinguished because it is said in that case the company was already in existence, that the venture was a joint venture between the English company and the French company, that the French company merely contributed to some share of the capital by the grant of a subsidy and land free of charge and that the work in fact was done by the South Indian Railway which was to pay gross receipts less working expenses to the Pondicherry company which divided the net profits after deduction of rates and taxes etc.

precedents.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co. v. Income-tax Commissioner
precedents.cited_proposition: payment out of profits and conditional on profits being earned cannot be described as payment made to earn profits

precedents.citation: The Union Cold Storage Co. Ltd. v. Adamson  H.M. Inspector of Taxes   2

anchor.surface_text: The Union Cold Storage Co. Ltd. v. Adamson  H.M. Inspector of Taxes   2  when they were sought to be made applicable to the facts in that case. Lord Macmillan said The obligation was conceived in language entirely different from the language which your Lordships have been considering in the present appeal, where there is a common form obligation in the lease to pay rent.

precedents.case_name: Union Cold Storage Co. Ltd. v. Adamson
precedents.cited_proposition: explanation of observations in Pondicherry case; rent deduction before ascertaining profits

precedents.citation: Indian Radio Etc. Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Indian Radio Etc. Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay 1  Lord Maugham delivering the opinion of their Lordships of the Privy Council observed at p. 278 - The sum is in truth made payable as part of the consideration in respect of a number of different advantages which the appellants derive from the agreement and not all of them can be shown to be of a purely temporary character.

precedents.case_name: Indian Radio & Cable Communications Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: payment for various advantages under agreement not allowable if like joint adventure

precedents.citation: British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd. v. Harris 1

anchor.surface_text: British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd. v. Harris 1  which the Tribunal said on the facts was nearest to the case before us, the company was carrying on business as manufacturers of beat sugar, had agreed to pay to two bodies in each of four years for division between them as they mutually agreed upon 20 of the net profits of the company in consideration of their giving to the company the full benefit of their technical and financial knowledge and experience,

precedents.case_name: British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd. v. Harris
precedents.cited_proposition: payment of share of profits to bodies providing technical/financial advice is deductible as trade expenditure

On a construction of the terms of the contract in this case and the obligations arising therefrom we cannot say that the conclusions of the Kerala High Court are unsustainable. The assessee had nochoice at the time of inception, as a condition of its coming into existence to agree to the several terms stipulated by the Government for transferring the profit earning assets
